noun.description: A hard, lustrous spherical mass, typically white or bluish-gray, formed within the shell of a pearl oyster or other bivalve mollusk and highly prized as a gem.
A precious thing; the finest example of something.
examples: the nation's media were assembled to hear his pearls of wisdom

verb.description: Dive or fish for pearl oysters.

proper noun.description: A city in central Mississippi, just east of Jackson; population 24,400 (est. 2008).

phrases: It was a true case of casting pearls before swine.
As a general rule, I advise against casting pearls before swine.
Oh, but even as I write I can't shake the feeling that I'm casting pearls before swine; that you don't believe a word of this, that you remain suspicious of my motives.
origin: Late Middle English: from Old French perle, perhaps based on Latin perna leg, extended to denote a leg-of-mutton-shaped bivalve.
